alert.note: Alert for Glades (Florida) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued September 29 at 3:32PM EDT until further notice by NWS Miami
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida... Fisheating Creek near Palmdale affecting Glades County. For the Lake Okeechobee/Fisheating Creek...including Ortona Lock, 12 midnight avg lake lvl, Moore Haven Lock, Fisheating Creek near Lakeport at Highway 78, Clewiston Ind. Canal, Palmdale...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. This approaches the flood of record. * WHERE...Fisheating Creek near Palmdale. * WHEN...Until further notice. * IMPACTS...At 8.0 feet, The water begins retreat from inside the main office and store in the campground. The Upstream campground and access roads to the campground are still completely flooded. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:00 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 6.9 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage early this evening and continue rising to a crest of 7.4 feet by Saturday morning. The river is then forecast to remain at 7.4 feet through Sunday evening before slowly falling to 7 feet by Tuesday morning. - Flood stage is 7.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 7.9 feet on 08/29/1949. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood && Fld Observed Forecasts (2 pm EDT) Location Stg Stg Day/Time Fri Sat Sun Fisheating Creek Palmdale 7.0 6.9 Thu 3 pm ED 7.2 7.4 7.4 &&
info.instruction: Stay tuned to further developments by listening to your local radio, television, or NOAA Weather Radio for further information. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely. This warning will be in effect until the river falls below its flood stage. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued late tonight at 330 AM EDT.
